header.title: Be a Goddess! A Guide to Celtic Spells and Wisdom for Self-Healing, Prosperity, and Great Sex
header.category: Western Esotericism, Occultism, Celtic Shamanism, Wicca, Self-Help Magic

central_thesis: The central thesis of this work is to provide a structured, step-by-step training in Faerie Tradition, a unique branch of Celtic shamanism and Wicca, enabling practitioners to achieve profound inner transformation, self-acceptance, and the manifestation of desired 'good things in life' through practical, ethical magic, emphasizing personal responsibility and deep connection to the divine in nature.

structure_content.chapter_title: From My Book of Shadows (Magical Journal)
structure_content.summary: The author introduces her unique perspective as a 'Fey sorceress' existing outside human history until this lifetime, tasked with teaching 'Fey magic' to humanity. She shares personal memories of past lives and magical experiences that inform her current work, emphasizing the ancient, subtle nature of Faerie magic.

structure_content.chapter_title: My Experience with the Faerie Tradition, in This Lifetime
structure_content.summary: De Grandis recounts her rigorous seven-year training in Celtic shamanism (Faerie Tradition) under Victor Anderson. She defines Faerie Tradition as a Wiccan branch focused on deep inner transformation, distinct from other Wiccan practices by its subtle, external-trapping-free approach, honoring both Goddess and God without gender stereotypes, and emphasizing personal purity and technical psychic skill.

structure_content.chapter_title: A Re-creation of an Ancient Practice
structure_content.summary: This section details the author's development of 'The Third Road' curriculum, designed to make Faerie Tradition safe and accessible to the general public. It aims to integrate mystic practice with everyday life, bringing together apparent opposites like discipline and freedom, and emphasizing self-respect tempered with humility for safe and effective magical practice.

structure_content.chapter_title: Preparing for an Ecstatic Journey
structure_content.summary: De Grandis explains the benefits of Wicca, including self-love, personal goal achievement, and experiencing the 'wild, natural power of Goddess Spirituality.' Through student examples, she illustrates how Wicca addresses emotional blocks, shame, and leads to practical improvements in daily life and material abundance, always stressing that love and sex are central to the Craft.

structure_content.chapter_title: What to Expect on a Shamanic Journey
structure_content.summary: The author outlines the book's pedagogical approach as a fifteen-week, step-by-step shamanic training, focusing on 'doing' rituals rather than just theory. It's structured to build psychic skill incrementally, enabling deep personal change and the integration of shamanism as a lifestyle. Emphasis is placed on the holistic involvement of one's 'whole being' in rituals for genuine transformation.

structure_content.chapter_title: How to Use This Book
structure_content.summary: This section provides practical guidance on engaging with the book's material, stressing the importance of active participation in rituals, self-reflection, and sequential learning for safety and effectiveness. It highlights prayer as a broader concept and cautions against adapting rituals initially to maintain their inherent power and safety.

structure_content.chapter_title: Shamanic Discipline and Self-Defeat
structure_content.summary: De Grandis defines shamanic discipline as the steady application of rituals and assignments to build magical skills, overcoming self-defeating inner voices of discouragement and fear. It distinguishes true discipline, which leads to freedom and joy, from abusive, restrictive practices, and encourages practitioners to trust the Gods' support in overcoming obstacles.

structure_content.chapter_title: First Weeks Lesson: The Old Gods Bless Everything We Do
structure_content.summary: This inaugural lesson introduces the practice of dedicating Wiccan work to the 'Old Ones' to receive their protection, guidance, joy, and love. It includes the 'Blessing the Path' ritual, emphasizing protection against mishaps and gaining an 'ancient witchy perspective' by invoking the Great Mother and Lord of the Dance.

structure_content.chapter_title: Love Is a Science, Science Is Mysticism
structure_content.summary: The author presents magic as a science harmonious with nature, where Wiccans see the Goddess and God in all things and laws of physics. She emphasizes that the cosmos is a living, cognizant, and sexual entity, and that spiritual life is not divorced from scientific laws or the physical body. A prayer, 'The Laws of Nature,' reinforces this connection.

structure_content.chapter_title: A Healthy Priest(ess) Makes All Things Sound
structure_content.summary: This concept emphasizes that individual health and well-being are interconnected with the health of family, community, and nature. Self-care is presented as a primary responsibility and a means to effectively serve others, challenging the notion that self-neglect is spiritual. The section illustrates how neglecting personal needs can have detrimental effects on one's ability to help others.

structure_content.chapter_title: Second Weeks Lesson: Love Your Body and Be Cleansed in Spirit
structure_content.summary: This lesson focuses on self-love and spiritual cleansing, preparing the practitioner to become a 'clean channel' for the Goddess's love and energy. It introduces a 'Prayer That You May Love Your Body and Be Cleansed in Spirit,' emphasizing healing from unhealthy shame and embracing the body as sacred and a direct reflection of the divine.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Great Mother Brings Life and Death
structure_content.summary: De Grandis explores the Goddess's multifaceted nature, particularly her threefold aspects: Maiden (Nimue), Mother (Mari), and Crone (Ana). These aspects embody freedom, creativity, nurturance, death, and transformation, challenging narrow societal definitions of female roles and emphasizing the Goddess's presence in all stages of life.

structure_content.chapter_title: Third Weeks Lesson: To Be Truly Human Is to Be Truly Divine
structure_content.summary: This lesson redefines the Wiccan God as a being of life, vitality, joy, and fertility, contrasting with fearful, punitive deities. It emphasizes that 'to become Godlike means to become fully human and fully animal,' honoring innate integrity and passion (Self-fire). Transcendence is discussed as healthy when balanced with respect for the sacred material world, avoiding abusive forms.

structure_content.chapter_title: Fourth Weeks Lesson: An Altar Is a Place of Power
structure_content.summary: De Grandis explores the concept of the Celtic altar, not as a place removed from the world, but as a consecrated 'place of power' connecting practitioners to the Gods and nature. It stresses that the altar is a reflection of the self and can be a workbench for magic, incorporating natural objects and embodying personal goals, with the ultimate altar being one's own body and spirit.

structure_content.chapter_title: Fifth Week Lesson: A Child Dancing in the Rain
structure_content.summary: This lesson introduces 'Pre-ritual Purification' as a necessary step for all rituals, ensuring the practitioner is a 'clear channel' for divine energy and can work safely with wild forces. It involves identifying and asking the Gods to remove internal blocks like resentment, fear, or worries that hinder effective ritual work, emphasizing that this cleansing allows one to be 'fully ourselves'.

structure_content.chapter_title: Sixth Weeks Lesson: Gifts of the Great Mother
structure_content.summary: This lesson emphasizes pleasure and joy as core tenets of paganism, stating, 'All acts of love and pleasure are my rites.' It argues that seeking ethical pleasure is not selfish but leads to service and personal fulfillment, aligning with the Mother Goddess's intention for humans to enjoy life. It provides a 'Magical Bath' ritual for pure pagan pleasure.

structure_content.chapter_title: Seventh Week Lesson: Finding Endless Sources of Power
structure_content.summary: This lesson focuses on drawing power from natural elements and within oneself. It explains that the 'etheric energy-matter' of the universe is alive, vital, cognizant, and sexual, making life itself sacred. Rituals like 'Energy Contemplation' and 'Breathing Exercise' are introduced to help practitioners tap into this primal life force and integrate it for personal empowerment.

structure_content.chapter_title: Eighth Week Lesson: Being Whole
structure_content.summary: This lesson details the 'Psychic Anatomy of the Three Souls': the conscious self, the Godself (Dian-y-glas or Aumakua), and the unconscious (fetch or inconscious). It emphasizes the integration of these three aspects for self-knowledge, personal authority, and connection to nature, introducing 'The Ha Prayer' to facilitate this wholeness and allow the Godself to fully participate in daily life.

structure_content.chapter_title: Ninth Week Lesson: Pride and Sex Are Holy
structure_content.summary: This lesson challenges societal views on pride and sex, asserting their sacredness within Wicca. It promotes healthy pride, self-worth, and embracing sexual desire as God-given and holy. It also includes a 'Purification by Water' ritual to cleanse internal blocks related to sexuality and to prepare the practitioner for the 'Cup of Love' spell.

structure_content.chapter_title: Tenth Week Lesson: Don't Be Lonely
structure_content.summary: This lesson focuses on deepening the connection with oneself, the Earth, and the Old Gods through an advanced grounding ritual ('Grounding no. 2'). It emphasizes feeling oneself as a moving, breathing, dancing part of the Earth, allowing for a profound sense of belonging and overcoming feelings of isolation, reinforcing the idea that spirituality is lived in every movement.

structure_content.chapter_title: Eleventh Week Lesson: The Ethics and Laws of Wicca
structure_content.summary: This lesson delves into the ethical framework of Wicca, asserting that magical ethics are inextricably linked to the 'psychic laws of nature.' It cautions against forcing one's will on others, emphasizing the 'threefold return' of magical actions. The author provides practical guidance on helping others without controlling them, stressing common sense and personal accountability in spellcrafting.

structure_content.chapter_title: Twelfth Week Lesson: Healthy Spirituality Means Striving for the Good Things in Life
structure_content.summary: This lesson encourages practitioners to cast spells for mundane desires and 'good things in life,' such as love, money, and a home, arguing that this is a spiritual act, not 'unspiritual.' It introduces 'Visualization Techniques' as a core magical skill for shaping reality, emphasizing precision, emotional engagement, and focusing on the desired results rather than the means or involving others without consent.

structure_content.chapter_title: Thirteenth Week Lesson: A Cup of Love
structure_content.summary: This lesson introduces a comprehensive three-part love spell, 'The Cup of Love,' designed to create true love and romance. It emphasizes that love and sex are fundamental forces of creation and powerful healing magic. The first rite, 'The Cleansing of the Vessel,' involves deep self-examination and purification of internal blocks related to receiving and giving love, ensuring the practitioner is a 'fit vessel'.

structure_content.chapter_title: SECOND RITE: The Filling of the Vessel
structure_content.summary: This second rite of the love spell focuses on cultivating self-love and inner fulfillment, asserting that one must fill their own 'vessel' before expecting a lover to do so. It involves carrying a personal 'self-love bundle' and encourages self-reflection on what one mistakenly expects a lover to provide, guiding practitioners to address these needs independently.

structure_content.chapter_title: THIRD RITE: Placing the Cup on the Altar
structure_content.summary: The final rite of the love spell focuses on inviting true love into one's life by creating a psychic 'call' for romance without manipulation or force. It involves crafting a symbolic representation of one's desired relationship and anointing it while praying to the Mother for a true mate. The ritual emphasizes courtesy in the psychic realm and trust in the Gods' choice for the highest good.

structure_content.chapter_title: Fourteenth Week Lesson: Everywhere You Go, There's Power to Be Had
structure_content.summary: This lesson teaches 'nonritualistic' magic for exerting control and creating harmony in everyday environments without interfering with others' wills. It advocates for using herbal magic, candles, and incense as 'psychic decor' to infuse spaces with desired energies, emphasizing that true power is cooperative and that self-care through magic benefits the broader community and planet.

structure_content.chapter_title: Fifteenth Week Lesson: Merry Meet and Merry Part
structure_content.summary: This concluding lesson encourages practitioners to reflect on their journey, acknowledge their growth, and reward themselves. It provides guidance for continued spiritual development on the Faerie path, emphasizing patience, self-acceptance of imperfections, and utilizing the learned tools in daily life. It reiterates that magic is for living fully, with joy, purpose, and integrity.

key_concepts.definition: A branch of Wicca/Celtic Shamanism focused on deep inner transformation, developed by the author based on rigorous training with Victor Anderson. It is subtle, often without external trappings, feminist, and rooted in ancient village witch practices.

The author's proprietary curriculum for teaching Faerie Tradition. It aims to reconcile apparent opposites (e.g., discipline and freedom, mysticism and practicality), making ancient magic accessible for modern self-healing and personal growth.

A foundational ritual structure used in Faerie Tradition to ensure safety, effectiveness, and proper engagement with magical work. It typically includes pre-ritual cleansing, the Ha prayer, grounding, blessing the path, the main body of the ritual, and closing devocations/prayers.

An inherent part of each person, the 'God within,' often perceived as a blue sphere above the head. It is a loving parental deity that answers prayers and provides guidance. The Hawaiian term Aumakua means 'parent' or 'I am parent.'

The part of the self closest to nature and intuition, often wrongly labeled 'unconscious.' It communicates directly with the Gods and the Godself, creating and storing energy, and appreciating art and poetry. Integrating the fetch with the conscious mind is a key goal.

The invisible etheric energy-matter that constitutes all of reality. It is alive, vital, cognizant, and sexual, forming the basic life force and the substance out of which all things are made. It is the raw material used in spellcrafting.

A core shamanic discipline involving continuous self-cleansing of emotional, spiritual, and psychological toxins. It’s an ongoing process to become a clear channel for divine energy, prevent destructive magic, and facilitate personal growth, not implying innate badness but a continuous journey toward wholeness.

In Celtic shamanism, darkness is understood not as evil or a mere opposite to light, but as a loving, vital, and fecund force at the heart of creation. It is the mirror through which essential selves are found, offering rest, recovery, and deep healing.

The concept that rituals are not just formal acts but creative, expressive forms of worship and magic that permeate daily life. This includes art, culinary abilities, humor, and any activity that expresses oneself and connects to the Gods.

An ancient name for the Wiccan God, representing a holy integrity and passion that burns within each person. It signifies the untamed, sacred passion for life that modern post-pagan societies often suppress.

A crucial shamanic skill involving willingness to surrender to the will of the Gods and the universe, especially when one's own desires seem blocked or misdirected. It means not forcing events but trusting a higher plan, leading to a relaxed, happy life.

A psychic law stating that anything a person does magically (good or bad) returns to the doer multiplied by three. It serves as an ethical guideline, emphasizing personal accountability for magical actions.

The idea that magic operates according to natural, scientific laws, just as physical phenomena do. It implies that certain actions in the psychic realm will cause predictable results, regardless of personal belief or chant, underscoring the need for precise knowledge and ethical practice.

practical_system.description: The author's practical system, 'The Third Road,' is a comprehensive, step-by-step training in Faerie Tradition, a unique blend of Celtic shamanism and Wiccan practices. It emphasizes deep inner transformation, self-acceptance, and manifesting desires through ethical, embodied magic. The system's core philosophy is that magic is a 'psychic physics' where thought and emotion directly shape reality, and that the divine (Goddess and God) is immanent in all things, including the self and nature. Practitioners are guided through 'endless purification' to clear internal blocks, cultivate a healthy ego, and integrate the 'three souls' (conscious, Godself, fetch) for wholeness. The system stresses practicality, encouraging the application of magic in daily life ('nonritualistic rituals') and using tools like visualization, prayer, and specific ritual frameworks. Ethics are paramount, guided by common sense and the 'threefold return' law, ensuring magic is used for the highest good and respects personal autonomy.

So She gave us the material world as Her sacred gift and, in another measure of Her practicality, made sure we had tools—magical spells—to make the most of Her gift.

A shamanic lesson is a complex, nonlinear dance. Bring your whole being to the experience and dance with me. Use your mind, heart, intuition, and gut feelings. Layers upon layers will be revealed to you simply by doing the rituals.

The Mother Before Creation is walking in the outer darkness. Her steps touch nothing, Her steps touch Herself, who is all things. She uses space as a mirror. This mirror is known as the Mirror of Darkness.

The existence of the Godself does not contradict the existence of a supreme deity, nor is praying to one or the other exclusive. A shaman prays to the Gods with her whole being; her Godself takes part in that process.

critical_analysis.relevance: Franceska De Grandis's 'Be a Goddess!' is a significant work within modern esoteric and occult literature, particularly for its unique articulation of 'Faerie Tradition' and 'The Third Road.' It offers a pragmatic, embodied approach to magic, bridging traditional Celtic shamanism with contemporary self-help paradigms. Unlike many texts that present magic as purely symbolic or detached from daily life, De Grandis insists on the literal efficacy of psychic physics and the sacredness of the material world, including sex and mundane tasks. Her emphasis on 'endless purification' as a continuous, internal process for safe and effective magic, rather than a punitive one, distinguishes her method. The book's strength lies in its comprehensive integration of psychological insight with magical practice, challenging practitioners to confront self-sabotage and cultivate self-love as foundations for external change. It contributes to a broader understanding of Wicca as a path of personal sovereignty and responsibility, moving beyond simplistic 'love and light' narratives to embrace the 'dark heart' of creation and healthy anger. The detailed guidance on visualization, ritual pacing, and the 'Magic Formula' makes it a practical manual for transformative work.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The book is primarily targeted at individuals interested in Wicca, Celtic Shamanism, and personal spiritual development, particularly those seeking a practical, results-oriented magical system for self-healing, prosperity, and fulfilling relationships. It caters to both beginners and 'advanced practitioners' (defined as those with six or more years of serious study in Wicca or self-taught magic), offering specific instructions and adaptable assignments for different experience levels. The author's direct, conversational tone, combined with the structured 'week lessons,' makes complex esoteric concepts accessible. Those who resonate with feminist spirituality, a holistic view of the divine, and an emphasis on ethical responsibility will find the book particularly appealing. It is also suitable for individuals looking to integrate their spiritual practice deeply into their daily, mundane lives, rather than treating magic as an isolated or purely ceremonial activity. The author explicitly cautions against using the rituals as a substitute for professional counseling for psychiatric issues, indicating an audience willing to engage in holistic self-improvement.
